pros: One of the best jobs I’ve had
cons: Most jobs are temporary there

job_title: Senior Patient Access Representative in Orange, CA
pros: Great benefits, access to the 24/7 medical library lounge, sleeping pods, and higher salary than other hospitals in Orange County.
cons: This review is particularly for the call center department (Patient Access Team)-this department feels like a replica of high school, but worse. At first management makes you feel like a impeccable asset to the department, then you will endure psychological abuse after being groomed. They have a iron-clad promoting "system" where only management gets promoted. There has to be an issue when a significant portion of the staff are on FMLA for stress, depression and anxiety. Although it's remote work, you continuously are micromanaged throughout the workday-it feels immensely bureaucratic. Management also makes you feel guilty for applying to other departments. You can't complain to HR because management always wins.

pros: Good benefits Holiday pay PTO Sick time
cons: Monthly productivity goal Some managers micromanage

job_title: Medical Affairs Analyst in Orange, CA
pros: Hybrid schedule, no micro managing
cons: No training given, learning as I make mistakes

pros: Great colleagues, very good leadership. Pay and benefits are decent.
cons: Missing some mid to executive leadership positions due to difficulty filling jobs. Somewhat surprised that a big entity will make significant admin mistakes, but they are always willing to fix them. Some mid level leaders are only okay. Pay is not on par with other providers such as MD or DO.

review_title: Good if you came prime a private practice.
pros: Since it’s a large medical facilities, there are separate job titles that will do things MAs normally do for small clinics. As an MA you don’t typically draw blood, ekgs, et cetera.
cons: You pay for parking if you work at the medical center.

pros: Great pay and benefits, lots of resources, friendly staff.
cons: I have none at this point.

pros: Great learning opportunity to learn case management skills and still be hands on with patient care.
cons: Extremely busy outpatient clinics, not well organized.

job_title: Sr vocational nurse in Orange, CA

job_title: Patient Senior Access Representative in Orange, CA

cons: Micro management, because it’s remote we don’t always get quick help if we have a question, no pay raise only through union, union dues, hard to get days off especially if someone requested the day.

pros: No continuity of management. CEO and other C-suite positions changed every 2-5 years. Physician jobs have no protection. Lack of professionalism in management and among physicians. No comradery.
cons: Great benefits if employed more than 5 years. Pension payed out in 5 year blocks.

pros: Pension, Define Job Classes, Great Environment and Events
cons: Paid Parking, Sometimes requires commuting.

review_title: Good benefits, poor management in some facilities

review_title: Great place if you have a good manager
job_title: Licensed Vocational Nurse (LVN) in Irvine, CA
pros: Good pay, great benefits, multiple medical plans to choose from varying in costs to fit your budget, holiday pay, PTO, vacation accrual, sick time accrual. Pension, 401k, 403b plans.
cons: The departments run smoothly when you have a good manager, when theres not a good manager a lot of things get overlooked and it can be chaotic. Leadership is as usual not in touch with what happens on the floor, but if you've been in health care for a while you already know this is typical.

pros:
Best Hospital in USA and best ER in Ca
	
Pros
Seasonal work, allowing you the employee built in vacation time. The ability to move around and train in different areas of people photography. Portraits and sports photography. Best advice to employees, keep on the positive side and you will be worked and get hours. Near the end of the season you may not get many hours
cons:
Good Work Place and good benefit

Either early morning having to get up 3 to 5 am to be at the job by 7-8 am. some times on retake days you are there less time then it took for your drive time one way, because of where you live and the location of the school. Poor planing on the schedulers in my opinion. The logic in assign jobs to employees does not make sense

review_title: Overall good, but it will vary from department to department
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Orange, CA
pros: People and coworkers are fantastic (this may be hit or miss depending on department... there are a lot of them); leadership was great when I was there, though a bit volatile, so this may no longer be the case; great benefits with lots of options; cushy, pleasant working environment; cafeteria food is great; this health system really does make a positive difference in the community and provides a great learning experience for future doctors, and those are both things to be proud of.
cons: Hit or miss work experience depending on what department you work in, employee parking lot and shuttle service for low level staff is atrocious, parking enforcement is ridiculously stringent and loves giving employees parking tickets at any possible opportunity, interfacing with the low-performing departments is a nightmare (if that's in your job description), compensation is likely to be below industry average depending on what you're doing, ability to actually get stuff done is often hamstrung by cumbersome and/or outdated policies (welcome to healthcare, I guess) and plenty of red tape

pros: Benefits such as 401k, paid vacation, paid holidays, and healthcare are a huge plus.  You will also gain a lot of experience and a greater understanding of how a teaching facility functions.   The ability to witness the positive effects of innovative patient care is inspiring.
cons: Due to the Board Of Regents oversight and the hospitals affiliation wth the state of California as a teaching facility this is a HIGHLY political environment.  Almost cut throat.  Union involvement for non-exempt staff doesn't help.  A lot of back biting which is counter productive to a team environment.

review_title: Great Job, so much experience to gain
pros: I love the staff here.  Most units get along with each other and help each other out.  Teamwork is huge here, and we always are offering to help.  There are many learning opportunities because this is a level one trauma center, especially in SICU.  But for the most part, its a friendly environment with many resources.
cons: The pay is low, but fairly competitive than hospitals around the area.  There are politics and drama, but that's like any other job, especially in the hospital.  Parking also is a pain because you pay 40 dollars for parking, which is 2 blocks away.  A shuttle takes you, but sometimes you would have to wait 30 minutes just to get picked up from the shuttle.

pros: I was initially on the fence about leaving my prior industry to go into health care administration, but I have been very happy with my choice since coming to work for UCI Health.   The staff I work with is professional and warm and for the first time in my career, I feel genuinely valued and at ease in my job.   The physical work environment is very nice and the chiefs of staff in our department continuously go out of their way to express their appreciation for our efforts.  So far I am very happy.  The pension is great (and rare), and paid time off/holidays are abundant.
cons: The pay does start out a bit less than the private sector, however just the cost of benefits in my previous job would devour the higher pay I received.

review_title: Disorganized management, inexperienced staff leads to copious amount of stress
job_title: Administration (Non Clinical Role) in Orange, CA
pros: Work-Life Balance good. Working remotely accepted.
cons:
Executive Management does not believe in communicating to their teams and managing the communication internally. Lack of communication and planning causes tremendous stress and inefficient working conditions.

Unrealistic expectations from management. Everything is escalated to high priority, because no one plans ahead.

Very combative environment with the blame game being played too often.
Organizational chart changes far too frequently. Some areas don't even have an org chart available for review, so one never knows how to escalate a problem.

Internal processes are out of control (bad or non existent)!!

job_title: Supervisor Case Manager in Buena Park, CA
pros: It is a teaching institution and it is rewarding to be able to educate all the new Residents, nursing students, and new hires on the hospital's policies, procedures, and to be a resource guide to my staff of RN Case Managers and Social Workers.  I enjoy teaching!
cons: Not able to teach as much on the subject matters of nursing as much as I would like to, because of the position I hold as a supervisor over nurse case managers and social workers.

pros:
New hospital so everything is new
Cute nurses 
Close to some good restaurants
Everyone leaves everyone else alone
New cafeteria
cons:
Horrible parking availability 
Getting parking tickets are a guaranteed if you have no permit
Nurses are incapable of doing their work or refuses to work
Salary is definitely way below market 
Most of the "good" or more popular physicians are leaving, due to better offer somewhere else
No respect between departments and individuals

pros: Ridiculously generous time off programs, retirement (who has a pension anymore), and the employees more often than not are really passionate about the work they do.
cons: New CEO seems to have 0 interest in the operations of the medical center, lots of new c-level executives, so not sure the direction of the organization.  Silly politics with campus and within the UC system.  Too much union presence is disruptive and costly to the organization, what hospital can afford to give 6%+ annual raises?!  Accountability is spotty, depending on department.

review_title: Pretty good company to work for overall
pros: They are huge, have a multitude of positions, jobs, department. I loved working for them, they just have a great vibe and good people-- at least as far as I came across.
cons: Nothing I can think of that made me have any negative feelings towards except for maybe the fact that it's a highly competetive place to work at. So if for some reason you have half a reason to temporarily leave, no matter how good you are, you will most likely be replaced. However i'm sure each department is different and this a very subjective thing to say.

pros: have good benefits and decent paid working in the hospital. the working hours are firm and you will be given clear directions to accomplish department objectives
cons: the structure is somehow loose sometimes the pace is too slow and the responsibilities are not clear defined so that you will need to work on wide range of different things at the same time

pros:
- Self-funded vs. the UC campus organizations
- Passionate people that do amazing work
- Growing and adjusting to the new face of the healthcare industry
cons:
- Some reluctance for change in certain areas
- Organizational relationship with UCI campus can create challenges at times

pros:

job_title: Clinical Nurse I in Orange, CA
pros: flexible scheduling, no more than 4 days on at a time, 8 hrs overtime available per week, lots of learning (new residents), full benefits while part time
cons: difficult to switch between part time and full time, many nurses speak Tagalog on the floor or during shift report, experienced nurses not always welcoming to new nurses, double charting (electronically and paper charting for now), parking is expensive, lots of fees/dues taken out of pay check each month

pros: The benefits are amazing !!!! From $25 for PPO to best coverage of eye and dental coverage at no cost.
cons: Too many old(age) managers who really are stuck in their ways (Been managers for 20+ years) are not willing to hear or even consider changes unless it comes from corporate. Corporate is ran be old, white, republican homophobics. They treat you well when they want.

pros: Fantastic retirement benefits. Good personnel to work with-very dedicated. Typically very good working conditions in most facilities.
cons: Departments sometimes have budget cuts which are unexplainable and employees lose their jobs without any real warning. It also seems like departments can be at war with each other.

review_title: Great benefits, but difficult to maneuver

pros:
- Work/Life Balance
- Benefits/Retirement Plan
- Sense of teamwork throughout the department
- Opportunity for exposure into different parts of the department and organization
- Genuine attitudes of executive leadership
cons: - Getting certain things done faster would be nice, but given this is a government job at a university hospital, you have triple the amount of regulations to worry about so patience is very helpful to have.

pros: Great working hospital academic environment with ample opportunity for ongoing growth and professional development in the field of brain science and medicine.
cons: Long hard hours at a minimum are expected to be a part of the active team at this academic facility.

pros:
Base Salary ( ok if you demand Market rate before accepting offer)
Great place to gain experience
cons:
Pension will cost you 7-8% of your pay ( Make sure you account for it before accepting offer)
Parking ( you have to pay for it)

review_title: Negative Culture & Constraining to Overall Success
pros: Decent benefits and PTO (although other companies in Orange County have plans that are just as good); great company/buzzword to have on your resume; satisfaction that knowing your hard work - no matter how far removed - was to help a patient in need.
cons:
*It is clear that there are a group of people in upper management that could care less about the level of care our patients receive and are only focused on their own agendas. This is unfortunate because there are some new higher level leaders that seem to care very deeply about pushing this hospital forward. 

*Communication is horrible across the organization. Bottom line. 

*Morale is low in a lot of departments because resources are so low. Obtaining approval for more team members/replacements is difficult and cut backs on staff are putting a strain on many different teams throughout the hospital - both clinical and non-clinical. Employees will eventually burn out and make mistakes with patients if resources are not provided soon. 

*Little to no opportunity for movement, especially as positions are cut and there is zero focus on career development. 

*Many HR team members have left (and have not been replaced) within the past year which makes it seem as though something bigger is going on. There used to be positive energy and better involvement from the HR leader and that does not exist anymore. 

*Historically unfriendly environment where people do not say hello, good morning, or engage in small talk with each other.

review_title: Temp Medical Assistant at UCI MC
pros: Able to work alongside and network with All of the doctors and nurses. It left me constantly learning something new.
cons: Only given two days notice, the week before thanksgiving, that all temp MAs were longer needed. Two days to find a new source of income was pretty heartless...

job_title: Programmer Analyst I in Orange, CA
pros: Great benefits and solid pay for public employer.  Co-workers really made the job worth while.
cons: Management, didnt appreciate or ecourage growth of the employees.  Upper management caused the fall of this environment by using poor choices and failing to properly prioritize the needs of the company.

pros: Magnet hospital. Clean and nice facility. People are nice
cons: Frequent phone call(anytime: day or night) from unit asking if I can work. Worked as a part time RN but felt like on call nurse and also frequent floating. Had to take shuttle to get to the hospital and need to pay $40/month

pros: Well respected employer, great benefits, worked with some amazing people (although all the great ones are leaving due to the current environment).
cons: The new CEO is horrible. He's a really bad communicator and doesn't seem to know what he's doing.  All he seems to care about is the academic side of things.  It's not at all an employee-friendly environment anymore.  Even HR seems to be taking a turn for the worse which is not a good sign.

pros: The best benefits ever, a pension plan, 401K.  One of the best  hospitals in the country, Level 1 Trauma Center, Burn Center, Primary Stroke Center.  Excellent educational opportunities.
cons: BUSY!  Everything is audited!

pros: Compassionate management in the Diagnostic Radiology Department. Opportunities are available in radiology to cross train and advance career. Great co-workers.
cons: Can be extremely busy at times. Level 1 trauma center and number of specialties means having to work with some very ill/ challenging patients. Technology changes rapidly so be prepared to re-train frequently.

pros: Benefits were outstanding, and can't be matched by other competitors.  Orange campus is nice, with opportunities to meet peers outside in park-like environment.
cons: Lack of management experience in running health centers.  Way behind in managed care expertise, with a top-down culture that penalizes those who question  current practices.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Orange, CA

cons: Management of departments is a bit questionable in some areas but overall, a nicely run ship

pros: good co-workers, friendly environment, great benefits
